poem:
A Reader's Grace

In Barnes, where whispers of the Thames glint,  
Prunella reads unactorish airs,  
her voice a feather, brushing Larkin's ink  
into the quiet wind.  
  
Betjeman listens, bound in a chair  
of silence, eyes tracing the light  
of her syllables.  
  
Words find their freedom there,  
where the river meets the voice  
and the past drifts gently onward.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Letter: Prunella Scales obituary Prunella Scales, my neighbour in Barnes, south-west London, in the 1960s, was gifted as a superb reader of poetry. Together with Michael Hordern, Richard Pasco and Janet Suzman, she read the poems in John Betjeman’s 1977 BBC TV “aerial anthology” of film, poetry and music, The Queen’s Realm: A Prospect of England. Betjeman, himself an incomparable reader of poems, particularly admired her “unactorish” rendering of Philip Larkin. When Betjeman was incapacitated by a". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
